I feel like this would be a nightmare to do, all kinds of variables like the each stone having differing weights, the strength of the adhesives used which would having different values depending on where in the structure it was located. Ex. mortar's strength after years of being exposed to the elements vs the mortar in the center of the structure being shielded from the elements.

That would just an assumption to day if buildings are intact, the quake must be of lower magnitude. That may also mean the building is very nicely built.  Also it's not fare whether the quake is a 6.3 or 6.4 as 6.4 is ten times more intense than 6.3

In North India, and in places like Bihar (cradle of ancient Indo-Gangetic civilization and cultural hearth; and also a seismically active region), the structures in the entire city has some impact of past earthquakes. The linear cracks in the ancient rock caves and temples is very obvious and nothing but earthquakes could have created them. I myself was amazed how even after visiting few kilometres apart, the ancient structures had seismic cracks. I could therefore relate a lot with this video.

If you can present it in a palatable way, seismic interferometry (in theory) is able to measure what would have been recorded at a seismic station from an earthquake, however many years after the earthquake occurred you like. The earthquake could have occurred 20 years ago, and yet the right set up and maths lets you construct what you would have recorded! You break causality!

Archeoseismology; I'm reminded of the 1999 thriller novel Thunderhead by Preston & Child about the discovery of a spectacular cliff city. The archeologists discover earthquake damage that preceded the city's abandonment. And the damage is directly related to a peril threatening everyone, and no, it's not the potential for structural collapse, it's something you would never guess I wager, but it is a peril that exists in the real world. I recommend it highly!

It appears more and more scientists are experts in less and less. In Victorian times the scientists would be expected to be knowledgeable on the whole field of science, many of todays scientists are experts in something that amounts to almost nothing.

It would seem to me that such archeo-damage assessment could give an approximate Mercali intensity, but not an energy release magnetude, as shaking, and thus damage, is affected, not only by earthquake energy released, but also by such things as distance from the fault, ground quality, wetness.  An earthquake which occurred far away would give damage similar to a much smaller earthquake close by, soft ground exacerbates shaking and weakens ground support, wet building materials (as might be seen in the rainy season) are heavier, and may be weaker, and thus more suceptable to ground acceleration.

If you like archeoseismology, you may enjoy historical seismology and paleoseismology.

Both have been utilized in the New Madrid Seismic Zone. The former looks like things like newspaper reports to build an intensity/shake map hundreds of years later, while the latter looks at things like sandblows and broken stalagtites in caves to try and date earthquakes in the distant past.

This happens sort of in Mexico City with the ruins of the Aztec captial of Tenochtitlan, too: There used to be a giant series of lakes in the area, with Tenochtitlan and other cities being either on the shorelines or on islands, Tenochtitlan actually being built out of a series of artificial islands with venice like canals running through it. Today when there are earthquakes, the loose lakebed sediment shakes differently then the rest of the land, so the former lakebed and locations of Aztec cities shows up on seismograms and can be uses for stuff.
